educational_objective: Manage atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease risk with a heart-healthy diet.
question_text: A 38-year-old man seeks dietary advice to reduce his risk of myocardial infarction, stroke, and peripheral vascular disease. Family history is significant for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) He has no other traditional risk factors for ASCVD and is moderately physically active.On physical examination, blood pressure is 128/75 mm Hg. BMI is 24.Laboratory studies:LDL cholesterol98 mg/dL (2.54 mmol/L)
question_stem: Which of the following diets is most appropriate to recommend to this patient?
critique: A Mediterranean diet (Option D) or plant-based diet emphasizing intake of vegetables, fruits, legumes, nuts, whole grains, and lean vegetable or animal proteins (preferably fish) is recommended for all adults by the American College of Cardiology (ACC)/American Heart Association (AHA) to decrease atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) risk. Intake of trans fats, processed meats, refined carbohydrates, and sweetened beverages should be minimized. For adults with overweight or obesity, counseling and caloric restriction are recommended for achieving and maintaining weight loss. Plant-based and Mediterranean diets have consistently been associated with lower risk for all-cause mortality than control or standard diets.The ketogenic diet (Option A) is a high-fat, very-low-carbohydrate diet that produces metabolic changes associated with starvation and is known to have benefits in patients with epilepsy. Low-carbohydrate diets appear to be more effective than low-fat diets for short-term weight loss, but the long-term effects, including on ASCVD, are not established.Cardiovascular risk is associated with elevated LDL cholesterol levels. Treating patients at increased risk for ASCVD with LDL cholesterolâ€“lowering medications reduces cardiovascular mortality. However, the cardiovascular disease link to dietary cholesterol is weak. Dietary guidelines in the United States recommend healthy choices and limited dietary cholesterol, but do not specifically limit daily cholesterol consumption to 300 mg or less (Option C).A low-fat diet (Option D) can produce weight loss but is not associated with improvements in ASCVD or blood pressure. Although the DASH (Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension) diet, which includes low-fat dairy products, will reduce blood pressure, cardiovascular risk, and overall mortality, and the Prospective Urban Rural Epidemiology study indicated that dairy intake was associated with a 23% lower mortality rate, other trials have indicated an 11% increase in cardiovascular mortality rate with dairy consumption compared with vegetable protein. Low-fat dairy is not recommended by the ACC/AHA to reduce ASCVD risk (Option D).
key_points: A plant-based or Mediterranean diet that emphasizes intake of vegetables, fruits, legumes, nuts, whole grains, and fish is recommended to decrease atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease risk.
references: Arnett DK, Blumenthal RS, Albert MA, et al. 2019 ACC/AHA guideline on the primary prevention of cardiovascular disease: A report of the American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association task force on clinical practice guidelines. Circulation. 2019;140:e596-e646. PMID: 30879355 doi:10.1161/CIR.0000000000000678
